status_message_cleaned: Atlantic Canada is currently seeing an outbreak of Trichomonosis. It is a bird parasite that affects the upper digestive tract of birds, limiting their ability to swallow and keep their food down. Although bird feeders and baths make it easier for us to watch birds in their natural habitat, they can be harmful during an outbreak. You can help slow down the spread of Trichomonosis by removing bird feeders and baths and following these simple steps: BIRD FEEDERS AND BATHS ) Take down your bird feeders and bird baths. During the summer, there is enough natural food available, so there is no need to worry. ) Wash them thoroughly with a weak bleach solution (5% sodium hypochlorite). ) Dispose of any wet or eed feed left around your bird feeders and baths. ) Refrain from putting them back in your yard until the cooler temperatures in the Fall. For more information on Trichomonosis: U9

text_original:
Atlantic Canada is currently seeing an outbreak of Trichomonosis. It is a bird parasite that affects the upper digestive tract of birds, limiting their ability to swallow and keep their food down. 

Although bird feeders and baths make it easier for us to watch birds in their natural habitat, they can be harmful during an outbreak. You can help slow down the spread of Trichomonosis by removing bird feeders and baths and following  these simple steps: 

BIRD FEEDERS AND BATHS
1) Take down your bird feeders and bird baths. During the summer, there is enough natural food available, so there is no need to worry. 
2) Wash them thoroughly with a weak bleach solution (5% sodium hypochlorite).
3) Dispose of any wet or exposed feed left around your bird feeders and baths.
4) Refrain from putting them back in your yard until the cooler temperatures in the Fall.

For more information on Trichomonosis: http://ow.ly/Qr7y30dZhU9

text_original:
Looking for a way to contribute to conservation? Citizen scientists play an important role in many of our monitoring programs and provide biologists with invaluable information. 

While on a recent vacation to Cuba, nature photographer and citizen scientist, Alan Chaplin, did not know the Piping Plover he was snapping photos of was extraordinary. He reported the band only to discover that this bird had outlived its average lifespan by more than 4 times! 

The 17-year old plover was spotted near the same location our biologists banded it in 2000. It bred on Cavendish Beach in Prince Edward Island National Park in the early 2000s but had not been reported in over a decade. This resight is extremely useful for our scientists in understanding this at-risk species. 

Piping Plover continue to be marked in Canada, now with uniquely coded leg flags. For information on how to report a banded Piping Plover: http://ow.ly/8cAr3090oBx

The proposed designation of Scott Islands as the first marine National Wildlife Area will complement the five protected islands that make up the Scott Islands archipelago. 

Located off the northwest tip of Vancouver Island, British Columbia, the Scott Islands support the highest concentration of breeding seabirds in the Canadian Pacific. This includes:
‚Ä¢ 90 percent of Canada‚Äôs Tufted Puffins
‚Ä¢ 95 percent of Pacific Canada‚Äôs Common Murre
‚Ä¢ 50 percent of the world‚Äôs Cassin‚Äôs Auklets 
‚Ä¢ 7 percent of the global population of Rhinoceros Auklet

Find out more: http://ow.ly/b0w8306Rria

Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with the Nature Conservancy of Canada and local donors to greatly expand the Montagnes Vertes nature reserve around Mont Sutton to protect important wildlife habitat while continuing public access to the area‚Äôs natural beauty. http://ow.ly/GIfM303GsYE

Wild salamanders play a vital role in Canada‚Äôs ecosystems as part of the food web and in nutrient and carbon cycling. If the fungus enters Canadian ecosystems, the impacts on our native salamanders could be devastating.

A new restriction temporarily prohibits the import of all species of salamanders, newts and mudpuppies, for one-year, unless authorized by a permit issued by Environment and Climate Change Canada. 

A deadly disease-causing fungus, suspected to have spread from Asia via the pet trade, has been devastating salamander populations in Europe.  Wild salamanders play a vital role in Canada‚Äôs ecosystems as part of the food web and in nutrient and carbon cycling. If the fungus enters Canadian ecosystems, the impacts on our native salamanders could be devastating. http://ow.ly/zZLd30ccnnz

status_message_cleaned: Did you know the Lobster Bay area near Yarmouth, N.S., is the only place in Canada where you can find the Eastern Baccharis, a rare species of shrub? This species, also called the Groundseltree, is a member of the Atlantic Coastal Plains Flora, a group of flowering plants, shrubs and herbs, many of which are legally listed under the Species at Risk Act. In fact, only mature Eastern Baccharis plants exist today. Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect hectares of marshland on Roberts Island in Lobster Bay. These lands are not only home to the Eastern Baccharis, but also provide important habitat for water birds, including the black duck, long-tailed duck and green-winged teal.

text_original:
Did you know the Lobster Bay area near Yarmouth, N.S., is the only place in Canada where you can find the Eastern Baccharis, a rare species of shrub? This species, also called the Groundseltree, is a member of the Atlantic Coastal Plains Flora, a group of flowering plants, shrubs and herbs, many of which are legally listed under the Species at Risk Act. In fact, only 3000 mature Eastern Baccharis plants exist today.

Environment and Climate Change Canada is working with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect 20 hectares of marshland on Roberts Island in Lobster Bay. These lands are not only home to the Eastern Baccharis, but also provide important habitat for water birds, including the black duck, long-tailed duck and green-winged teal. http://ow.ly/4mKjtY

status_message_cleaned: Attention, wildlife enthusiasts! Did you know that from mid-April until the end of May, an Environment and Climate Change Canada team will be taking to the skies to count the ducks and geese breeding in and around the water bodies in the St. Lawrence Lowlands? Travelling by helicopter, the observers will identify and count all the species present, including Mallards, American Black Ducks and Wood Ducks. Back in the office, the team will compile the data, which will be used to provide a portrait of Quebec‚Äôs waterfowl populations.

Did you know that a significant number of toiletries such as scrubs and toothpastes are known to contain thousands of minuscule pieces of plastic called microbeads? These end up in our waterways and ultimately in the marine food chain. 

Today, we‚Äôre taking another important step to phase out the use of microbeads and protect the long-term health of our environment. Let‚Äôs keep Canada‚Äôs lakes and rivers clean! We want to hear from you during the 75-day consultation period on these proposed Microbeads in Toiletries Regulations. Submit your comments to the following e-mail address: ec.produits-products.ec@canada.ca, by January 19, 2017. http://ow.ly/lUNl305VJxM

status_message_cleaned: A healthy lake requires nutrients. However, when nutrient levels become too high they lead to excess algae growth that can degrade water quality and harm ecosystem health. In Lake Erie, one of the five Great Lakes, too much of the nutrient phosphorus has caused large scale algae blooms. We have adopted targets to reduce the amount of phosphorus entering Lake Erie. From farmers to home owners, everyone can practice phosphorus reduction activities! 0u

50th Anniversary of the Great Winnipeg Blizzard 

Winnipeg‚Äôs winter of early 1966 was the third coldest year of the century. To make matters worse, on March 4, 1966 a big snow storm piled up 38 cm and was driven by winds gusting up to 112 kilometers per hour. It was the worst winter storm ever recorded for Winnipeg since March 1902 and stranded thousands.

status_message_cleaned: Dr. Victoria Tschirhart is a Natural Resources Canada research scientist with the Geo-mapping for Energy and Minerals (GEM) program. status_message_cleaned: In partnership with Nature Conservancy of Canada / Conservation de la nature Canada, the Government of Canada is investing more than $2 million through the Natural Areas Conservation Program to support the protection of an additional hectares of old-growth forest lands in the heart of the Oak Ridges Moraine, the southern Ontario's most significant landforms. The Moraine lands are home to numerous species of wildlife, including many birds listed as at-risk under federal legislation, such as the Acadian Flycatcher and the Canada Warbler.

status_message_cleaned: Over the past five decades, the area covered by sea ice in Canada's Arctic has been decreasing at an unprecedented rate. This shrinking has an effect on the safety of northerners who use the ice as transportation routes or platforms for hunting and fishing. Wildlife, such as polar bears that depend on the ice for their survival, is also affected as their food supply and habitat diminish. Take some time to learn more about the impacts of a changing climate on Canada's sea ice.

status_message_cleaned: The Bartholomew River, which runs through the Miramichi region of New Brunswick, has long been a favourite destination for anglers. The wild Atlantic salmon that ply its waters support recreational fisheries and are an important food source for Indigenous communities. Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect the Bartholomew River and restore and enhance this important salmon habitat. Protecting the river and its adjacent forestland from future development will improve water quality and help to regulate the water temperature of the river, improving fish health.

status_message_cleaned: Shirley is an applied ecology technician at Environment and Climate Change Canada. Her work involves planning and conducting several types of aerial waterfowl surveys, including monitoring breeding pairs in the spring, Barrow‚Äôs Goldeneye in winter and the Common Eider at various times of year. She also takes part in duck and goose banding operations, which gives her a chance to travel to various locations in Quebec. Her work involves flying in helicopters at low altitudes with a lot of changes in direction (not for the queasy!). What she loves about her job is the combination of field and office work. Her advice to women who are interested: take the time to find a career where you can combine your interests, abilities and values.

text_original:
Shirley is an applied ecology technician at Environment and Climate Change Canada. Her work involves planning and conducting several types of aerial waterfowl surveys, including monitoring breeding pairs in the spring, Barrow‚Äôs Goldeneye in winter and the Common Eider at various times of year. 

She also takes part in duck and goose banding operations, which gives her a chance to travel to various locations in Quebec. Her work involves flying in helicopters at low altitudes with a lot of changes in direction (not for the queasy!).

What she loves about her job is the combination of field and office work. Her advice to women who are interested: take the time to find a career where you can combine your interests, abilities and values. #WomenScienceDay

status_message_cleaned: Did you know that clean air is essential not just for humans but for wildlife, vegetation, water, and soil? Poor air quality occurs when pollutants reach high enough concentrations to endanger human health and/or the environment. The levels of these pollutants in outdoor air are influenced by many factors, including the proximity to local emission sources, weather conditions, chemical reactions in the air and the transport of air pollutants over long distances by winds. Learn more about air quality in your area:

Canada is committed to investing in programs that protect the land, water and air. #Budget2017 has made key investments in Indigenous Guardians Program, a program that employs as the "eyes on the ground" in Indigenous territories.

link_name: Photos from Environment and Natural Resources in Canada's post
status_message_cleaned: Did you know that two science weather supersites have been built in Iqaluit and Whitehorse? The weather information required in the North differs from what the population uses in the rest of Canada. For example, blowing snow and ice-fog are critical information for northern communities; more relevant than the temperature and humidity. Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs Weather Science team will use the data from the supersites to better understand and support weather forecasts that are more relevant to the needs of the people living in the North.

Did you know that two science weather supersites have been built in Iqaluit and Whitehorse? The weather information required in the North differs from what the population uses in the rest of Canada. For example, blowing snow and ice-fog are critical information for northern communities; more relevant than the temperature and humidity. 

Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs Weather Science team will use the data from the supersites to better understand and support weather forecasts that are more relevant to the needs of the people living in the North. #ArcticScience

text_original:
Randle Reef is an area of contaminated sediment located in Hamilton Harbour approximately 60 hectares in size. It contains 695,000 cubic metres of contaminated sediment at the bottom of the harbour ‚Äî a volume that would fill a major hockey arena three times over. 

The clean-up project will cost $138.9 million and will be completed in 2022. Environment and Climate Change Canada and the Ontario Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change have each committed $46.3 million, with the final third of funding coming from the City of Hamilton, the City of Burlington, Halton Region, the Hamilton Port Authority and U.S. Steel Canada. 

Check us out on YouTube ‚Äî search word ‚ÄúRandle Reef‚Äù and online at www.randlereef.ca.

text_original:
The Little Brown Bat, also known as the Little Brown Myotis, is listed as endangered under the Government of Canada's Species at Risk Act. Once wide-ranging and numerous, populations of these bats have declined steeply in recent years due to habitat loss, human disturbance of colonies, and white-nose syndrome, in which a fungus grows on the bat‚Äôs skin causing death.

Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect 178 hectares of wildlife habitat in central Saskatchewan. This area is home to the Little Brown Bat as well as many other species at risk, including the Northern Long-Eared Bat and Canada Warbler. http://ow.ly/XA3P304qWH7

Once found widely across the prairie provinces, its population has declined by almost two-thirds since due largely to habitat loss! Today, this majestic bird is listed as threatened under the Species at Risk Act. To help give ferruginous hawks and other wildlife species a chance to thrive, Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to conserve more than ,200 hectares of prairie grassland in Alberta's Porcupine Hills region. This land will be protected in perpetuity under the Government of Canada‚Äôs Ecological Gifts Program.

text_original:
The magnificent Ferruginous Hawk, with a wingspan that can reach 1.5 m, is one of the largest species of hawks. Once found widely across the prairie provinces, its population has declined by almost two-thirds since 1992 due largely to habitat loss! Today, this majestic bird is listed as threatened under the Species at Risk Act.

To help give ferruginous hawks and other wildlife species a chance to thrive, Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to conserve more than 1,200 hectares of prairie grassland in Alberta's Porcupine Hills region. This land will be protected in perpetuity under the Government of Canada‚Äôs Ecological Gifts Program. http://ow.ly/vk9F3060ACR

status_message_cleaned: Canadian Solar was founded in in Guelph, Ontario, and is one of the three biggest solar companies in the world by revenue. There are over ,700 employees working in countries on six continents, making it a global leader among clean technology companies. In June , Ert Development Canada (EDC) announced $91 million in financing to Canadian Solar to aid in the construction of the Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park in Dubai, which when completed, will be the most powerful solar power plant in the world. In addition to the project being groundbreaking in size, Canadian Solar is using innovative practices to maximize efficiency as well. The park will use tilting panels to track the sun, rather than standard conventional solar power arrays.

text_original:
Canadian Solar was founded in 2001 in Guelph, Ontario, and is one of the three biggest solar companies in the world by revenue. There are over 9,700 employees working in 20 countries on six continents, making it a global leader among clean technology companies. 

In June 2017, Export Development Canada (EDC) announced $91 million in financing to Canadian Solar to aid in the construction of the Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum Solar Park in Dubai, which when completed, will be the most powerful solar power plant in the world.

In addition to the project being groundbreaking in size, Canadian Solar is using innovative practices to maximize efficiency as well. The park will use tilting panels to track the sun, rather than standard conventional solar power arrays.

Hunters: what do you think about the proposed changes to the Migratory Birds Regulations? 

1) The Government of Canada would discontinue the issuance of bait authorizations; 
2) The Government of Canada would prohibit the deliberate modification of an agricultural crop for the purpose of attracting migratory birds for hunting. For example, intentionally flooding a standing cornfield.

The consultation period ends on February 17. Take a look at the consultation document and share your feedback! http://ow.ly/h3C9308Qb4k

Canadian wetlands provide enormous benefits to people by protecting against floods, improving water quality and water supply, controlling erosion and supporting a variety of recreational activities. Although the importance of wetlands is being recognized more and more; many of Canada‚Äôs wetlands in settled areas have been lost, and Canada continues to lose these important habitats ‚Äì both naturally and because of human-related activities. The National Wetland Conservation Fund (NWCF) supports organizations and communities across Canada to participate actively in the restoration and enhancement of degraded wetlands. For example, an NWCF project led by Ducks Unlimited Canada enhanced hectares of wetland habitat throughout N.B., N.S. and P.E.I. Find out more about NWCF:

text_original:
Happy #WorldWetlandsDay! Canadian wetlands provide enormous benefits to people by protecting against floods, improving water quality and water supply, controlling erosion and supporting a variety of recreational activities. 

Although the importance of wetlands is being recognized more and more; many of Canada‚Äôs wetlands in settled areas have been lost, and Canada continues to lose these important habitats ‚Äì both naturally and because of human-related activities.

The National Wetland Conservation Fund (NWCF) supports organizations and communities across Canada to participate actively in the restoration and enhancement of degraded wetlands. For example, an NWCF project led by Ducks Unlimited Canada enhanced 140 hectares of wetland habitat throughout N.B., N.S. and P.E.I. 

Find out more about NWCF: http://ow.ly/ZE4W308C2Am

status_message_cleaned: Cool tech alert! Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs climate scientists mapped snow depth transects using self-recording GPS depth probes shown here. They each have backpacks with rechargeable batteries linked to a data-logger and a GPS antenna to record depth probe readings. These on-the-ground measurements help scientists better understand the characteristics of tundra snow. The data collected was used to refine computer models used to predict climate change. For reference: C. Derksen, P. Toose, A. Rees, L. Wang, M. English, A. Walker, M. Sturm, Development of a tundra-specific snow water equivalent retrieval algorithm for satellite passive microwave data, Remote Sensing of Environment, Volume , Issue , August , Pages -1709.

Cool tech alert! Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs climate scientists mapped snow depth transects using self-recording GPS depth probes shown here.

Migratory birds are a vital part of Canada‚Äôs environment, eating insects, dispersing seeds and pollinating plants. Their natural beauty and seasonal migrations are integral to Canada‚Äôs heritage. Nature NB recently received $125,000 through the Environmental Damages Fund‚Äífunding that came from a court penalty associated with a situation where thousands of migratory birds were killed. The project will research migratory bird migration and raise public awareness about the importance of migratory birds in southern New Brunswick.

status_message_cleaned: Kathy is a Senior Research Scientist at Environment and Climate Change Canada and a Professor of Wildlife Ecology at the University of B.C. Kathy studies the ecology and life history of alpine and arctic songbirds and grouse across different elevations. Her research program has led to about scientific papers, changes in forest operational practices and management recommendations for endangered species. Kathy received the Ian McTaggart Cowan Lifetime achievement award in which recognizes individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the understanding, conservation and/or management of wildlife in Canada over their career.

text_original:
Kathy is a Senior Research Scientist at Environment and Climate Change Canada and a Professor of Wildlife Ecology at the University of B.C. Kathy studies the ecology and life history of alpine and arctic songbirds and grouse across different elevations.  Her research program has led to about 200 scientific papers, changes in forest operational practices and management recommendations for endangered species. 

Kathy received the Ian McTaggart Cowan Lifetime achievement award in 2016 which recognizes individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the understanding, conservation and/or management of wildlife in Canada over their career. #BecauseOfHer

status_message_cleaned: Let‚Äôs celebrate today! It marks the launch of a new edition of the World Meteorological Organization's International Cloud Atlas. Clouds are one of the key uncertainties in the study of climate change: we need to better understand how clouds affect the climate and how a changing climate will affect clouds. Let‚Äôs celebrate #WorldMeteorologicalDay today! It marks the launch of a new edition of the World Meteorological Organization's International Cloud Atlas. 

Clouds are one of the key uncertainties in the study of climate change:  we need to better understand how clouds affect the climate and how a changing climate will affect clouds. The new Atlas contains hundreds of images of clouds, including a few newly classified cloud types. It also features other meteorological phenomena such as rainbows, halos, snow devils and hailstones. Check it out: http://ow.ly/1MNb30aaBMc

status_message_cleaned: Sarah is a Wildlife Research Technician at Environment and Climate Change Canada. She is motivated to take real action on conservation goals, and is fascinated by evolutionary and behavioural ecology. She is inspired by the critters she works with, that persevere in spite of what happens around them, and the people who are passionate about their conservation. Sarah advises women to listen to their internal voices and chase those dreams. Try new things and keep an open mind. You never know what you‚Äôll end up being great at.

She is motivated to take real action on conservation goals, and is fascinated by evolutionary and behavioural ecology. status_message_cleaned: In the Sackville, N.B. area? For a peak at the artwork, check our page next week!

status_message_cleaned: Some Canadian companies, from Loblaws, to Canadian Tire, to the five big banks, have come out strongly in support of a price on pollution. Canadian companies are choosing cleaner options as they produce and sell their products. They are making their operations more efficient. And they are putting bold ideas into action and creating good-paying middle-class jobs and opportunities in the process. Countries from China to Chile to those in the European Union, and American states like Oregon and California ‚Äì the sixth largest economy in the world ‚Äì are all pricing carbon pollution. These major economies are putting a price on carbon pollution because it works, and because it is the most effective way to reach our emissions reductions goals while growing strong economies.

text_original:
Some 30 Canadian companies, from Loblaws, to Canadian Tire, to the five big banks, have come out strongly in support of a price on pollution.

Canadian companies are choosing cleaner options as they produce and sell their products. They are making their operations more efficient. And they are putting bold ideas into action and creating good-paying middle-class jobs and opportunities in the process.

Countries from China to Chile to those in the European Union, and American states like Oregon and California ‚Äì the sixth largest economy in the world ‚Äì are all pricing carbon pollution. 

These major economies are putting a price on carbon pollution because it works, and because it is the most effective way to reach our emissions reductions goals while growing strong economies.

In 2006, the Musquash Estuary on the Bay of Fundy was designated New Brunswick's only federal Marine Protected Area. Now, on the tenth anniversary of its designation, the Government of Canada is pleased to partner with the Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional 35 hectares of this ecologically-sensitive wetlands habitat.

The Musquash Estuary is also a key point on the Atlantic Flyway, a major bird migration route. The location, remoteness and position of the Estuary wetlands provide excellent habitat for migratory sea ducks, particularly black scoter and white-winged scoter. http://ow.ly/4mZUc2

status_message_cleaned: Did you know for more than years, Canada and the United States have conducted a large-scale banding program on the Canadian Prairies? Each August, biologists from Canadian Wildlife Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife work together to band thousands of birds prior to their annual migration as part of the Western Canada Cooperative Waterfowl Banding Program. Last Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary is one of sites where the banding takes place. Ducks flying south from Canada to the U.S. and beyond are tracked through reports to the Canadian Wildlife Service Bird Banding Office and the U.S. Geological Survey. Reports of banded bird encounters help document their longevity, movements and sources of mortality. This data helps scientists better understand migratory birds, determine appropriate regulations and ultimately contribute to their survival.

text_original:
Did you know for more than 60 years, Canada and the United States have conducted a large-scale banding program on the Canadian Prairies? 

Each August, biologists from Canadian Wildlife Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife work together to band thousands of birds prior to their annual migration as part of the Western Canada Cooperative Waterfowl Banding Program. Last Mountain Lake Migratory Bird Sanctuary is one of 12 sites where the banding takes place. 

Ducks flying south from Canada to the U.S. and beyond are tracked through reports to the Canadian Wildlife Service Bird Banding Office and the U.S. Geological Survey. Reports of banded bird encounters help document their longevity, movements and sources of mortality. This data helps scientists better understand migratory birds, determine appropriate regulations and ultimately contribute to their survival.

On Friday, December 9, 2016, the Pan-Canadian Framework on Clean Growth and Climate Change was adopted.

This historic achievement for Canada represents Canada‚Äôs first ever federal, provincial and territorial plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, grow the economy and build resilience to a changing climate.

It puts Canada on a pathway to meet its 2030 target and fulfil our global commitment under the Paris Agreement. 

Way to go Canada! üá®üá¶ http://ow.ly/x49p3096sib

Oak Lake and Plum Lake lie at the heart of an extensive system of wetlands in southwestern Manitoba near Brandon. Each year, tens of thousands of waterbirds -- including Franklin's Gull, Snow Goose and Tundra Swan -- descend on the lakes as part of their annual migration cycle. 

Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional 47 hectares of wetlands habitat in the Oak Lake and Plum Lake area. This initiative demonstrates our ongoing commitment to the North American Waterfowl Management Plan, which was signed by the governments of Canada and the United States in 1986 and later by Mexico in 1994. http://ow.ly/gm6e3077u6g http://ow.ly/VMbJ3077u7c

status_message_cleaned: Quiz time for kids: Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called? - Carbon footprint - Carbon sinks - Carbon magic Encourage your children and students to learn about climate science by playing the Climate Science Brain Buster Quiz on the Climate Kids website. ANSWER: Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called carbon sinks. Carbon sinks such as oceans, forests and wetlands remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by absorbing it like a sponge. We can help reduce effects of climate change by protecting natural ecosystems that are carbon sinks.

Quiz time for kids: Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called?
- Carbon footprint
- Carbon sinks
- Carbon magic

Encourage your children and students to learn about climate science by playing the Climate Science Brain Buster Quiz on the Climate Kids website.
https://climatekids.ca/ 

 
ANSWER:
Oceans, forests and wetlands that take carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere are called carbon sinks.
Carbon sinks such as oceans, forests and wetlands remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by absorbing it like a sponge. We can help reduce effects of climate change by protecting natural ecosystems that are carbon sinks.

Many of these pieces of land contain areas designated as being of national or provincial significance, and are home to some of Canada‚Äôs species at risk. For example, the MacPhail family donated 33 hectares of mature Wapane‚Äôkati or Acadian forest in Elmwood, PEI to Island Nature Trust  to ensure the land is conserved! 

They will make sure that habitat is protected for local song birds, small mammals, amphibians and other wildlife. For more information about how to donate land that is important to you and our environment: http://ow.ly/OzFf306PmkR

status_message_cleaned: years ago, the UV Index was launched by Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs scientists. Two years later, it was adopted by the World Health Organization and the United Nations Environment Program, and it is now used internationally. The UV Index is a measure of the strength of the sun‚Äôs UV rays. It is based on the thickness of the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere, the angle of the sun above the horizon and the amount of cloud cover. As the UV increases, the sun‚Äôs rays can do more harm to your skin, eyes and immune system. Congratulations to Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs scientists for developing such a useful tool!

status_message_cleaned: Fact or fiction? A tree is a safe hiding place from lightning. When thunder roars GO, INDOORS! Fiction: No, in fact standing under a tree is one of the most dangerous places to be during a thunderstorm. Lightning can strike a tree and the current can travel down the trunk and exit two ways: it can side flash from mid-trunk and jump out and hit you. Or, the lightning can flow out through the roots and you can be hit by ground current. If you are in a forested area during a storm, stay on the trail, not near a tree, and keep everyone a few metres apart from each other. 9D

Fact or fiction? A tree is a safe hiding place from lightning. When thunder roars GO, INDOORS! 

Fiction: No, in fact standing under a tree is one of the most dangerous places to be during a thunderstorm. Lightning can strike a tree and the current can travel down the trunk and exit two ways: it can side flash from mid-trunk and jump out and hit you. Or, the lightning can flow out through the roots and you can be hit by ground current. If you are in a forested area during a storm, stay on the trail, not near a tree, and keep everyone a few metres apart from each other. http://ow.ly/hl2N30cCX9D

If you are a fisher, farmer or even an outdoors enthusiast, wetlands play a major role in your life. Wetlands support Canadians economically, socially and environmentally. Further, marshes, swamps, bogs, fens and shallow waters host a huge variety of life, protect our coastlines, act as natural sponges against flooding, and store carbon that helps regulate climate change. Let‚Äôs celebrate the importance of wetlands together. Happy World Wetlands Day! 

The Government of Canada is working with partner funding programs such as the National Wetland Conservation Fund to support projects that restore and enhance wetlands. http://ow.ly/XOGBY http://ow.ly/XOGFJ

status_message_cleaned: Each year, thousands of shorebirds and waterfowl can be seen on the beaches and lagoons of Miscou Island, off the coast of New Brunswick, during their fall migration. The Government of Canada is pleased to partner with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional hectares of this ecologically-sensitive wetlands habitat. By protecting the lands from development, this area will continue to serve as an important refuge for migratory birds such as the Piping Plover, listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act. Conserving coastal lands like these also benefits local communities by helping to mitigate the impacts of storms and rising sea levels associated with climate change.

text_original:
Each year, thousands of shorebirds and waterfowl can be seen on the beaches and lagoons of Miscou Island, off the coast of New Brunswick, during their fall migration. The Government of Canada is pleased to partner with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect an additional 47 hectares of this ecologically-sensitive wetlands habitat.

By protecting the lands from development, this area will continue to serve as an important refuge for migratory birds such as the Piping Plover, listed as endangered under the Species at Risk Act. 

Conserving coastal lands like these also benefits local communities by helping to mitigate the impacts of storms and rising sea levels associated with climate change. http://ow.ly/2cYz306wOnw

status_message_cleaned: Pointe-au-P√®re National Wildlife Area is one of the best shorebird-watching sites in Quebec. In the spring, flocks of Least Sandpipers congregate at the site, while Great Blue Heron feed in the marshes in the company of Black-crowned Night-herons and large communities of Brants. In the summer, American Black Ducks, Mallards, Northern Pintails and Green-winged Teals raise their young and feed on the plentiful invertebrates in the brackish ponds. During the fall migration, Red-throated Loon and Common Loon, and large numbers of Canada Geese, are observed. Large communities of Sanderlings and Semipalmated Sandpipers also use the area, along with the White-rumped Sandpiper.

Last week was the start of the hunting season in the Quebec Region. On September 23, through a joint operation between Environment and Climate Change Canada‚Äôs Wildlife Enforcement Branch and the Minist√®re des For√™ts, de la Faune et des Parcs du Qu√©bec (French only), hunters suspected of killing migratory birds illegally and violating laws and regulations surrounding the practice of this activity were intercepted. In total, 70 ducks were seized. An investigation is currently underway to lay charges against the hunters involved.

 
Before you go hunting, find out about the migratory bird hunting regulations for your area. Migratory birds are protected under the Migratory Birds Convention Act, 1994, but hunting of certain species, such as ducks and geese, is allowed during specific periods and in specific areas across Canada. 

To learn more about these regulations: http://ow.ly/gGWc30fzU4a

status_message_cleaned: Birds can sometimes cause damage to property or pose a threat to humans. You can scare migratory birds that are causing or are likely to cause damage, but it is prohibited to kill, wound or capture them. Be careful not to harm them and respect the Migratory Birds Convention Act, . text_original:
Birds can sometimes cause damage to property or pose a threat to humans. You can scare migratory birds that are causing or are likely to cause damage, but it is prohibited to kill, wound or capture them. Be careful not to harm them and respect the Migratory Birds Convention Act, 1994. 

For more information, contact Environment and Climate Change Canada's Public Inquiries Centre at 1-800-668-6767 or by e-mail at ec.enviroinfo.ec@canada.ca.

status_message_cleaned: The forests at Ramacieri in Quebec create a large unbroken chain of habitats for wildlife. Many species, including at risk salamanders, depend on this forest ecosystem. Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with the Nature Conservancy of Canada through the Natural Areas Conservation Program to protect this unique environment.

status_message_cleaned: Climate scientist Chris conducted a multi-kilometre snow transect across the tundra using self-recording GPS depth probes. For reference: C. Derksen, P. Toose, A. Rees, L. Wang, M. English, A. Walker, M. Despite its small size, √éles de la Paix National Wildlife Area hosts a diversity of habitats that regularly attract close to 130 species of birds. The islands provide nesting sites for several dozen pairs of ducks, and food and shelter to nearly 5,000 ducks in the spring and close to 30,000 during the fall migration. 

The area is also home to more than 150 species of animals and 50 plant species, including species at risk. http://ow.ly/M8lT30ct5IU

Today, Minister Jim Carr of Natural Resources Canada announced the creation of a Generation Energy Council to provide recommendations on how Canada can prepare for the reliable, affordable, low-carbon economy of the future. 

The Council will assemble takeaways from both the #GenEnergy forum and the six-month engagement that asked Canadians from across the country what their energy future looked like. 

Transforming how our society makes, moves and uses energy will redefine Canada‚Äôs energy future, resulting in good, middle-class jobs and a sustainable environment for future generations.

Today is National #LookUpAtTheSkyDay ‚Äì a day to take some time to look up at the sky! 

Did you know that 3.1 megatonnes of pollutants were directly released to air in Canada in 2015? Most are from a group of pollutants known as Criteria Air Contaminants, responsible for smog and acid rain. They include pollutants like carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds and particulate matter. 

To learn more about these and other releases to the environment, check out the National Pollutant Release Inventory‚Äôs Summary Report: http://ow.ly/3YOs30aQcIP

Bivalve shellfish such as oysters, clams, scallops and cockles feed on microscopic plankton in the water. status_message_cleaned: Air pollution is one of the most significant environmental problems affecting our health. It adversely affects our lakes and oceans, and causes acid rain and smog. Some of the air pollution in Canada comes from outside the country. That‚Äôs why Canada just ratified the Gothenburg Protocol, an international agreement to reduce air pollutants. Under the Protocol, Canada will continue taking action on air pollution by reducing these dangerous emissions. We‚Äôre taking action to provide Canadians with clean air and a healthier environment.

text_original:
Air pollution is one of the most significant environmental problems affecting our health. It adversely affects our lakes and oceans, and causes acid rain and smog. Some of the air pollution in Canada comes from outside the country. That‚Äôs why Canada just ratified the Gothenburg Protocol, an international agreement to reduce air pollutants. 

Under the Protocol, Canada will continue taking action on air pollution by reducing these dangerous emissions. 

We‚Äôre taking action to provide Canadians with clean air and a healthier environment.

Lake Erie needs your help! Harmful and nuisance algal blooms are hurting Lake Erie‚Äôs environment and economy, and present risks to human health. But a healthier lake is possible.

Canadians have until May 24 to comment on a draft action plan to help reduce the amount of phosphorus ‚Äì a key factor causing algae ‚Äì from entering the lake. Your comments and ideas will help build a final Plan with specific actions to help restore water quality in Lake Erie.

Public meetings are taking place on May 16 and 18 in the Lake Erie basin. Can‚Äôt make it in person?  Share your ideas online! www.letstalklakeerie.ca

status_message_cleaned: Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.

text_original:
Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). 

We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. 

Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.

status_message_cleaned: ‚Äì June , ‚Äì is a chance to celebrate Canada‚Äôs biodiversity! Biodiversity ‚Äì the life forms we eerience all around us, yet know remarkably little about. This wide array of ecosystems, ecological processes, species and genes is essential to our existence. Even as scientists discover new species (estimates suggest millions remain unknown), it is clear that our biodiversity is under threat ‚Äì from competing land uses, pollution, population growth and human activities. #WorldEnvironmentDay ‚Äì June 5, 2017 ‚Äì is a chance to celebrate Canada‚Äôs biodiversity!

Biodiversity ‚Äì the life forms we experience all around us, yet know remarkably little about. This wide array of ecosystems, ecological processes, species and genes is essential to our existence. Even as scientists discover new species (estimates suggest millions remain unknown), it is clear that our biodiversity is under threat ‚Äì from competing land uses, pollution, population growth and human activities.

Environment and Climate Change Canada and its partners work to conserve our biodiversity. Find out what we are doing to address this daunting global challenge. http://ow.ly/A8ds309wasW #WED2017

status_message_cleaned: Congratulations to Dr. Bell and the team from Memorial University of Newfoundland who created SmartICE. At the United Nations Climate Conference COP23, they received the UN Climate Solutions Awards for their outstanding work adapting to climate change. They developed a tool that helps Indigenous Peoples adapt to thinning sea-ice. The tool provides information to aid in the planning of safe routes on the ice, which helps to reduce travel risks. SmartICE‚Äôs work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted.

Congratulations to Dr. Bell and the team from Memorial University of Newfoundland who created SmartICE. 

At the United Nations Climate Conference COP23, they received the 2017 UN Climate Solutions Awards for their outstanding work adapting to climate change. They developed a tool that helps Indigenous Peoples adapt to thinning sea-ice. The tool provides information to aid in the planning of safe routes on the ice, which helps to reduce travel risks. 

SmartICE‚Äôs work underlines how global climate action is accelerating two years after the Paris Agreement was universally adopted. http://ow.ly/sD6G30gAhTI

Households use chemical pesticides and fertilizers to get rid of unwanted plants, insects and to keep up the appearance of lawns and gardens. But these chemicals can have negative environmental and health effects; they can pollute lakes and rivers and can be harmful to many forms of life including species that help the environment. 

Although Canadian households have been using less chemical pesticides and fertilizers since 1994, this use has increased in recent years. Check out Environment and Climate Change Canada's Canadian Environmental Indicators for the latest results:
http://ow.ly/INdg30gJjXb #CdnEnv #Sustainability #Indicators

Did you know that methane emissions can be seen with an infrared camera? Using this technology to spot leaks could help oil and gas facilities capture previously wasted gas.

If you‚Äôre in Northern Qu√©bec or Labrador regions, EDF still has $3.45M in funding available until October . A Qu√©bec company was ordered to pay $7.5M after pleading guilty to charges under the Fisheries Act. This is the largest penalty ever given for an environmental infraction. Last week was the first deadline to apply for funding through the Environmental Damages Fund (EDF). There‚Äôs still more available! If you‚Äôre in Northern Qu√©bec or Labrador regions, EDF still has $3.45M in funding available until October 31.

A Qu√©bec company was ordered to pay $7.5M after pleading guilty to 45 charges under the Fisheries Act. This is the largest penalty ever given for an environmental infraction. Environment and Climate Change Canada puts a lot of consideration into where the funds go. Of that $7.5M, $6.83 was directed to EDF and today $3.45 is available to fund projects that will benefit the affected area.

For more information about this Fund and to find out if your project qualifies for funding, click here: http://ow.ly/Cbb130e4RtF

status_message_cleaned: Birds can sometimes cause damage to property or pose a threat to humans. You can scare migratory birds that are causing or are likely to cause damage, but it is prohibited to kill, wound or capture them. Be careful not to harm them and respect the Migratory Birds Convention Act, . For more information, contact Environment and Climate Change Canada's Public Inquiries Centre at -800-668-6767 or by e-mail at ec.enviroinfo.ec.ca. 1 1

Birds can sometimes cause damage to property or pose a threat to humans. You can scare migratory birds that are causing or are likely to cause damage, but it is prohibited to kill, wound or capture them. Be careful not to harm them and respect the Migratory Birds Convention Act, 1994. 

For more information, contact Environment and Climate Change Canada's Public Inquiries Centre at 1-800-668-6767 or by e-mail at ec.enviroinfo.ec@canada.ca.

text_original:
We are creating a souvenir album celebrating 100 years of bird conservation in Canada. Share with us your bird anecdotes or thoughts on birds today!

The album will be a tribute to birds and all those who love them, volunteer bird observers, or those who have even devoted their career to bird conservation. The album will contain testimonials and photos of 100 people. 

Here‚Äôs how to participate :
-Write a 100-word anecdote about your work with birds, bird encounters or about your love of birds.
-Let us know your name and send a self-portrait taken outdoors (300 dpi).
-List your five favorite birds. 
ec.oiseauxmigrateurs-migratorybirds.ec@canada.ca #BirdYear

Looking beyond their current work and expertise, participants of the Generation Energy roundtable at Dalhousie University were asked for their vision of Canada‚Äôs future energy mix.

The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) submitted several proposals, and all were accepted! The GSC received the moon rocks and put them on display to the public. text_original:
In 1966, NASA invited scientific groups from around the world to submit proposals to study lunar material from the Apollo 11 mission. The Geological Survey of Canada (GSC) submitted several proposals, and all were accepted!

The GSC received the moon rocks and put them on display to the public. The collection included rock fragments, polished thin sections and soil. There was strong public interest, and long line-ups snaked their way into the GSC‚Äôs headquarters at 601 Booth Street!

If you live near Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, come visit Booth #9 at the Bio Expo 2017 this weekend and see how everyday electronics depend on earth‚Äôs rare metals.
http://ow.ly/vMFR30fiqJY

Micheline‚Äôs research focuses on caribou ecology and genetics in different regions of the country and internationally. She uses genetic methods to assess how landscape features affect the distribution, movement and abundance of caribou.

Micheline collaborates with Indigenous organizations and communities to bring the best knowledge to inform conservation issues.

status_message_cleaned: Ammonites are fossils of an unusual marine cephalopod invertebrates that went extinct about million years ago. Due to their distinct characteristics, paleontologists from around the world study, classify and use them as indicators of geological time periods. Today, different species have been found around the Pacific Rim, in Japan, Russia, Alaska, British Columbia and California. Their relatives ‚Äî squid, octopus and nautilus ‚Äî still live in today‚Äôs oceans.

Ammonites are fossils of an unusual marine cephalopod invertebrates that went extinct about 65 million years ago. Due to their distinct characteristics, paleontologists from around the world study, classify and use them as indicators of geological time periods.

Today, different species have been found around the Pacific Rim, in Japan, Russia, Alaska, British Columbia and California. Their relatives ‚Äî squid, octopus and nautilus ‚Äî still live in today‚Äôs oceans.
